subject: Re: [junit] Re: Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: As has already been suggested, don t export JUnit from VAJ, instead download a new JUnit release from http://www.junit.org and run outside VAJ to your heart s
messageBody:
As has already been suggested, don't export JUnit from VAJ, instead
download a new JUnit release from http://www.junit.org and run outside
VAJ to your heart's content. IBM has apparently "enhanced" the JUnit
they ship with VAJ so that it runs well inside VAJ, but not so well
outside. Most of us who use JUnit do not develop with VAJ.

Hope this helps,

Frank

On Wed, 2003-06-18 at 17:52, ok_lilya wrote:

> Rainsberger,
>
> I tried your suggestion but it still doesn't run. inVAJava() checks
> for Class.forName("com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport"); and since this
> class has to be linked with another ibm java class, it throws the
> same LinkageError: java.jang.UnsatistiedLinkError:no uvmtools in
> java.library.path
>
> And therefore, inVAJava doesn't return true and JUnit stalls.
>
> I created a very small program that only contains inVAJava() method
> and a main that calls it:
> public static boolean inVAJava() {
> try {
> Class.forName("com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport");
> }
> catch (Exception e) {
> return false;
> }
> return true;
> }
>
> main... {
> if (inVajava())
> System.out.println("true");
> else
> System.out.println("false");
> }
>
> Then I exported my program with package com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport
>
> Seems that inVAJava() never returns true when run outside of VAJ. It
> almost acts like a security feature - so that you can't run it ouside
> of VAJ. JUnit uses that method, that means that it will never return
> true unless running in VAJ.
>
> I've been stuck on this problem way too long - There must be somekind
> of solution to it! Unless JUnit is designed specifically to avoid
> being run outside of VAJ. I'm on the verge of giving up.
>
> If you have any other solution in mind, I would really appreciate it.
>
> Thanks so much.
>
> Lily.
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
> wrote:
> > >So said Jason Rogers on 2003-06-18 --------------------
> > >On Tue, 2003-06-17 at 18:55, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > >> I disagree. Model objects representing values should be
> transparent, a
> > >la "Naked Objects". They should let the Model objects containing
> business
> > >logic "do with them what they may". There is a tendency in OOP to
> pretend
> > >there is behavior where there is no behavior. I think that is a
> mistake.
> > >Some objects in the system are just bags of data. I think public
> fields
> > >should do nicely there. Ward Cunningham has been experimenting with
> > >ignoring the prevaling paranoia against public data. I haven't
> seen him
> > >write anything on it yet, but it's good to test long-
> standing "rules".
> > >
> > >I agree with that when it is applied to "data structures," the
> naked
> > >objects you refer to, but not behavioral objects. I don't think
> you
> > >were applying it to the latter, I just wanted to be clear.
> >
> > Exactly. I'm with you. Sometimes, it's just a bag of data. Maps
> would do.
> >
> > >> One counterexample is an object with 20 fields. Perhaps 20 set
> methods
> > >is clearer, at least in a language like Java with positional
> parameters.
> > >(In Smalltalk it's exactly the same, so it doesn't matter.) Should
> an
> > >object have 20 fields? Perhaps not, but some do. It is not clear
> that
> > >breaking that 20-field objects into four 5-field objects is any
> better.
> > >
> > >A twist on that... If that object needs to have 20 fields (which I
> don't
> > >believe it does) you can group fields together into other objects
> such
> > >that this object is a wrapper on 5 others, each with 4 fields.
> The data
> > >is still in one place, but it's creation is much less cumbersome
> and you
> > >can create it in a sane state.
> >
> > I don't know that this is better: now I have to build five or six
> objects, and not just one. I think the creation is *no less*
> cumbersome in this case. That has been my observation.
> >
> > Take care.
> >
> >
> > J. B. Rainsberger,
> > President, Diaspar Software Services
> > Let's write software that people understand.
> > http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
> > telephone: +1 416 791-8603
>
>
>
